reviews.review_msg: AR is one of those profs that you know genuinely cares about what he is teaching and wants his students to succeed. Hes very helpful explaining material and encourages questions. Readings were good for the most part but some weeks prepare for easily 100+ pages. Slides arent very helpful for studying so make sure to keep up with lectures!!

Interesting lectures, plus he's very accessible & friendly.  However does feel a little bogged down in minutia at times as he focuses quite a bit on the wording of journal articles + theories/frameworks. Good prof overall though! Final & essay were challenging but not overwhelming. Prior Middle East knowledge helps. Didn't use sourcebook much.

Perhaps the most knowledgeable history prof with his subject. It was a joy to hear him lecture. If you show up on presentation day not knowing what you're doing, he'll be very hard on you. Otherwise, going to his office hours were incredibly useful. I would talk more classes with him.
In contention for best Prof at SFU.  Excellent Prof, equally as great person.  Agreed with other comment, would attend lectures just for fun.
awesome history professor. if you are interested in the middle east, take a course with him.

All in all, good prof w/ succinct lectures. The readings, except the sourcebook, are almost useless. All you need to read is the into and conc. However, if one is taking this class for Group 3 requirements and has no background in Islamc history, I would highly recommend reading a few books on Islamic history and a survey of Iranian history.
He's a doll - unbelievably nice. Actually interested in his students, which is unusual for a prof who's been around that long.
I found his lectures where never cohesive and went back and forth in time periods. His lack of helpfulness for his papers made this course truly a disappointment.
Cleveland a better prof for Middle Eastern material. Unless you prefer intellectual history, then Maclean is the guy for you.
Hard, but reasonable. Lots of reading.
